sections.title: Know Your Retirement Number
sections.subtitle: Estimate the income you'll need and the savings required to support it

sections.title: What You'll Do
items: Estimate Social Security and pension benefits
Translate expenses into a savings target

sections.title: Start with Lifestyle Costs
sections.content: Retirement planning begins with the life you want to maintain. Break expenses into needs (housing, insurance, groceries), wants (travel, hobbies), and surprises (home repairs, medical). Use today's dollars first; we'll adjust for inflation later.

points.title: Retirement Age
points.description: Impacts how long your nest egg must last and when you can draw Social Security.

points.title: Withdrawal Rate
points.description: Many planners start with 4%, but adjust downward if markets worry you or healthcare is unknown.

points.title: Inflation
points.description: Assume 2.5%-3% annual inflation to keep projections realistic over multi-decade retirements.

sections.title: Rule of 25
sections.content: Multiply desired annual income by 25 to get a ballpark savings target. $60,000 per year needs roughly $1.5 million invested.

sections.title: Adjust for Other Income
sections.content: Account for guaranteed sources: Social Security, pensions, annuities, or rental income. Subtract these from total spending to find how much your portfolio must deliver. A higher guaranteed floor allows lower withdrawal rates.

sections.title: Retirement Needs Worksheet
steps: Download or recreate the provided worksheet template in a spreadsheet.
List annual expenses in today's dollars, grouped by needs, wants, surprises.
Apply a 3% inflation factor for each year until retirement.
Enter expected Social Security/pension amounts (use SSA.gov estimates).
Calculate the portfolio gap and multiply by 25 (or your preferred withdrawal factor).

sections.title: Stress-Test Scenarios
sections.content: Model an early retirement age, a late retirement age, and a bear market in the first five years to see how your plan holds up.
